choices.text: PDH complex is analogous to α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase
Fat can be converted to glucose, because PDH cycle is reversible
TPP, lipoic acid, coenzyme A, FAD, NAD are the coenzymes involved
PDH defect leads to lactic acidosis

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the oxidative decarboxylation of pyruvate to acetyl CoA is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fat can be converted to glucose, because PDH cycle is reversible

 

Option B:

 

  1. PDH COMPLEX:
  • Pyruvate is oxidatively decarboxylated to Acetyl CoA
  • The oxidation of Pyruvate to Acetyl-CoA is the irreversible route from glycolysis to the citric Acid Cycle. No alternate pathway to circumvent this step
  • Pyruvate dehydrogenase complex is analogous to the α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase (option A)
  • Multienzyme complex associated with the inner mitochondrial membrane
  1. PDH complex consists of 3 Enzymes: Pyruvate Dehydrogenase, Dihydrolipoyl Transacetylase and Dihydrolipoyl Dehydrogenase.
  2. 5 Coenzymes (option C): Thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP), Lipoamide, Coenzyme A, FAD and NAD+
  3. PDH defect leads to lactic acidosis (option D)
  4. Completely irreversible process: (option B)

 

There is no pathway available in the body to circumvent this step and glucose through this step is converted to acetyl CoA from which fatty acids can be synthesized. But the backward reaction is not possible, and there is no net synthesis of glucose from fat.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: True, the PDH complex is analogous to the α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase complex in terms of function and coenzyme requirements.

 

Option C: True, these coenzymes are all involved in the function of the PDH complex.

 

Option D: True, a defect in the PDH complex can lead to lactic acidosis because pyruvate is then preferentially converted to lactate by lactate dehydrogenase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The conversion of pyruvate to acetyl CoA via the PDH complex is an irreversible step in metabolism. This means that fat, which is broken down into acetyl CoA, cannot be converted back to glucose through this pathway. This is a fundamental concept in metabolism, as it explains why fatty acids cannot undergo gluconeogenesis to form glucose.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 173, Vasudevan 9/ ed: p 115

questions.text:
Examines the following diagram, illustrating the PDH complex and its enzymatic

 

 

 

components, labelled A, B, and C

 

What is the name of enzyme component 'C' within the PDH complex?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase        

 

Option D:

 

Dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase (E3) is the third enzyme in the PDH complex and is responsible for the reoxidation of the lipoamide groups in the complex. It transfers the electrons to NAD+, reducing it to NADH, which is then used in other metabolic processes such as the electron transport chain.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Pyruvate dehydrogenase: This is the first enzyme in the complex and is responsible for the decarboxylation of pyruvate.

 

Option B. Dihydrolipoyl transacetylase: The second enzyme in the complex, responsible for transferring the acetyl group to CoA to form acetyl-CoA.

 

Option C. Lipoamide: Not an enzyme but rather a cofactor bound to the enzymes in the PDH complex.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The enzyme part of the PDH complex is made up of three component enzymes.
  • PYRUVATE DEHYDROGENASE (ENZYME 1): Catalyses oxidative decarboxylation; Coenzyme: TPP; Enzyme bound hydroxyethyl TPP is formed
  • DIHYDRO LIPOYL TRANSACETYLASE (ENZYME 2): Hydroxyethyl group is oxidized to form acetyl group → transferred from TPP to lipoamide → acetyl lipoamide.
  • DIHYDROLIPOYL DEHYDROGENASE (ENZYME 3): Oxidation of lipoamide; cofactors: TPP, lipoamide and FAD are regenerated

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 173, Vasudevan 9/ ed: p 115

questions.text: The diagram below represents the various fates of pyruvate. Which letter on the diagram shows the reaction requiring biotin as a cofactor and is activated by acetylcoenzyme A?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) C    

 

Option B:  

              

  • Pyruvate carboxylase, a mitochondrial enzyme of gluconeogenesis, requires biotin and ATP for its essential function
  • Pyruvate enters the mitochondrion and is carboxylated to oxaloacetate. This reaction is important in maintaining an adequate level of oxaloacetate for the condensation reaction with acetylCoA .
  • If acetyl-CoA accumulates, it acts as both an allosteric activator of pyruvate carboxylase and an inhibitor of pyruvate dehydrogenase, thus ensuring a supply of oxaloacetate.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. B: Denotes PDH present in mitochondria, which oxidatively decarboxylates pyruvate to acetyl CoA.

 

Option C. D: Denotes ALT. Alanine is formed by transamination of pyruvate by the enzyme alanine aminotransferase (ALT), which requires PLP.

Pyruvate + Glutamate → Alanine + alpha ketoglutarate

 

Option D. A: Pyruvate kinase dephosphorylates phosphoenolpyruvate to pyruvate, which is a substrate level key glycolytic enzyme.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The role of biotin is a cofactor in the carboxylation reaction catalyzed by pyruvate carboxylase and how acetyl-CoA serves as an allosteric activator of the enzyme, linking the state of cellular energy to gluconeogenesis.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 165,166.

choices.text: Location: not seen in RBCs
No re-utilization of lactate for gluconeogenesis
Energy need explains the oxygen debt after exercise

questions.text: A 42-year-old marathon runner experiences muscle fatigue and laboured breathing post-race. Upon evaluation, a metabolic cycle is considered in understanding her physiological state, as shown below. Which statement is correct regarding the metabolic cycle illustrated?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Energy need explains the oxygen debt after exercise 

 

Option D:

                      

Cori's Cycle or Lactic Acid Cycle:

 

  • It is a process in which glucose is converted to lactate in the muscle; and in the liver this lactate is re-converted into glucose.
  • It prevents lactate accumulation & muscle cramps
  • Significance: During exercise, lactate production is high, which is utilized by liver to produce glucose and the process needs ATP.
  • The resultant increased oxygen consumption is the explanation for the oxygen debt after vigorous exercise

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Cahill’s cycle: It is also known as glucose-alanine cycle and occurs in fasting muscles.

 

Option B. Location not seen in RBCs: Lactate is released by exercising skeletal muscle and by cells that lack mitochondria such as RBCs into the blood.

 

Option C. No re-utilization of lactate for gluconeogenesis: Glucose is converted to lactate in the muscle and in the liver this lactate is re-converted into glucose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Cori cycle is energy-intensive, costing 6 ATPs in the liver to resynthesize glucose from 2 lactate molecules. During exercise, the body incurs an "oxygen debt," as it uses more oxygen to replenish ATP stores and clear the lactate produced, explaining the labored breathing post-exercise.

 

Ref: Harper30/e: p 556, Vasudevan 9/ed: p 114

questions.text: A pediatric team is evaluating a 6-month-old full-term baby girl who presents with failure to thrive, hypotonia, decreased muscle mass, head lag, and metabolic acidosis. Her blood work shows elevated levels of lactate, pyruvate, and alanine. These clinical findings suggest a deficiency in a key metabolic enzyme. Which enzyme is most likely to be deficient in this infant, given her clinical and laboratory presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pyruvate dehydrogenase

 

Option D:

 

  • The increased concentrations of pyruvate, lactate, and alanine indicates there is a block in the pathway from pyruvate towards TCA cycle.
  • A deficiency in pyruvate dehydrogenase → build-up of pyruvate.
  • Pyruvate has three fates other than getting converted to Acetyl-CoA by pyruvate dehydrogenase: conversion to oxaloacetate by pyruvate carboxylase (option C), reduction to lactate by lactate dehydrogenase (option B), and transamination to the amino acid alanine by alanine aminotransferase (option A).
  • As pyruvate builds up, an increase in lactate and alanine would be expected if pyruvate dehydrogenase was deficient.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Alanine aminotransferase: This enzyme is involved in the transamination of alanine to pyruvate. A deficiency would not likely result in elevated levels of pyruvate or lactate.

 

Option B. Lactate dehydrogenase: A deficiency in this enzyme would typically lead to lower levels of lactate, not higher.

 

Option C. Pyruvate carboxylase: While this enzyme is involved in gluconeogenesis, its deficiency usually leads to hypoglycemia and does not typically cause elevated lactate levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pyruvate dehydrogenase deficiency is characterized by the accumulation of pyruvate that cannot be effectively converted into acetyl CoA, leading to its reduction to lactate resulting in lactic acidosis and transamination to alanine

 

Ref: Vasudevan 9/e: p115-116,253-254.

choices.text: Administration of thiamine is expected to reduce his serum lactate level and improve his clinical symptoms.
A high carbohydrate diet would be expected to be beneficial for this patient.
Citrate production from aerobic glycolysis is expected to be increased.
PDH kinase, a regulatory enzyme of the PDH complex, is expected to be active.

questions.text: A neurology team is managing a 2-month-old boy with neurological symptoms and lactic acidosis. To determine the underlying metabolic issue, they perform an enzyme assay on extracts from the patient's cultured skin fibroblasts, assessing the activity of the pyruvate dehydrogenase (PDH) complex. They find that the complex operates at only 5% of the normal activity with a standard amount of thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP) but achieves 80% of normal activity with a much higher TPP concentration. What is the correct interpretation concerning the patient's condition and potential interventions?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Administration of thiamine is expected to reduce his serum lactate level and improve his clinical symptoms. 

 

Option A:

 

This child exhibits classic signs of pyruvate dehydrogenase (PDH) complex deficiency, specifically a thiamine-responsive form:

  • The PDH complex catalyzes the conversion of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA, feeding into the TCA cycle.
  • A deficiency in PDH activity leads to accumulation of pyruvate, which is instead converted to lactate → lactic acidosis.
  • The enzyme assay suggests a mutation affecting the enzyme's affinity (Km) for TPP, the coenzyme derived from thiamine.
  • High doses of thiamine increase intracellular TPP and improve PDH activity, thereby reducing lactate buildup and improving clinical outcomes.

 

Other Options:

  • Option B. High carbohydrate diet would be beneficial
    → False. In PDH deficiency, increasing carbohydrate intake leads to more pyruvate accumulation and worsened lactic acidosis. 
  • Option C. Citrate production from aerobic glycolysis is expected to be increased
    → Incorrect. Impaired PDH activity limits acetyl-CoA formation, the precursor for citrate synthesis, thus citrate production is decreased.
  • Option D. PDH kinase is expected to be active
    → Incorrect. PDH kinase inhibits the PDH complex. However, high pyruvate levels inhibit PDH kinase, making it inactive under these conditions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Thiamine (Vitamin B1) is the precursor for TPP, a coenzyme for PDH complex, α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase, and transketolase.
  • Some PDH deficiencies are thiamine-responsive, especially those with a mutated E1 subunit that has a high Km for TPP.
  • Thiamine therapy can significantly reduce serum lactate and improve neurological symptoms in responsive cases

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 165-167, 174.

questions.text: A genetic counselor is discussing the potential impact of enzyme deficiencies on metabolic pathways with a couple awaiting the birth of their child. The counselor explains that certain genetic conditions can disrupt normal metabolic processes. She asks the couple to consider the statement: "A defect in the pyruvate dehydrogenase (PDH) complex can lead to lactic acidosis." Is this statement true or false?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) True

 

Option A:

 

Explanation:

 

A PDH defect can indeed lead to lactic acidosis. The PDH complex is responsible for converting pyruvate to acetyl CoA, a step that links glycolysis to the citric acid cycle. If PDH is deficient or defective, pyruvate cannot effectively enter the citric acid cycle and is instead converted to lactate by lactate dehydrogenase. This can lead to an accumulation of lactate in the blood, resulting in lactic acidosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Significance of PDH Complex

 

  • Thiamine deficiency affect PDH and thereby the complete oxidation of Glucose
  • PDH defect can lead to Lactic Acidosis due to excess of pyruvate and conversion to lactate instead of acetyl CoA
  • Fat cannot be converted to glucose because of the irreversible nature of PDH

 

Ref: Vasudevan 9/e p:115-117.

questions.text: PG Junior Residents of Biochemistry department are discussing a complex case of metabolic disorder; a debate arises regarding the metabolic flexibility of pyruvate under various physiological conditions. A senior consultant poses a question to the team to clarify the understanding of pyruvate metabolism. Which of the following is a fate of pyruvate in human metabolism?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All the above

 

Option D:

 

Pyruvate is a critical metabolic intermediate that sits at the crossroads of several important pathways in human metabolism. All three of the listed conversions are physiologically significant fates of pyruvate:

  1. Conversion to Glucose (option A):
    • Pyruvate can be converted to glucose through the process of gluconeogenesis, which occurs primarily in the liver and kidneys
    • This process begins with the carboxylation of pyruvate to oxaloacetate by pyruvate carboxylase (requires biotin as a cofactor)
    • This conversion is particularly important during fasting states or when glucose is needed by tissues like the brain
  2. Conversion to Lactate (option B):
    • Under anaerobic conditions or during intense exercise, pyruvate is reduced to lactate by lactate dehydrogenase (LDH)
    • This reaction regenerates NAD+ from NADH, allowing glycolysis to continue
  3. Conversion to Oxaloacetate (option C):
    • Pyruvate can be directly carboxylated to form oxaloacetate by the enzyme pyruvate carboxylase
    • This reaction is crucial for both gluconeogenesis and anaplerotic reactions that replenish TCA cycle intermediates
    • The reaction requires ATP and the cofactor biotin

 

It's worth noting that pyruvate has additional important metabolic fates not mentioned in the options:

  • Conversion to acetyl-CoA by pyruvate dehydrogenase complex (requires thiamine, lipoic acid, NAD+, FAD, and CoA)
  • Transamination to form the amino acid alanine via alanine aminotransferase (ALT)

 

Educational Objective:

 

The major fates of pyruvate in human metabolism include:

  1. Conversion to glucose through gluconeogenesis (pyruvate carboxylase)
  2. Reduction to lactate under anaerobic conditions (lactate dehydrogenase)
  3. Carboxylation to oxaloacetate for the TCA cycle or gluconeogenesis (pyruvate carboxylase)
  4. Oxidative decarboxylation to acetyl-CoA (pyruvate dehydrogenase complex)
  5. Transamination to form alanine (alanine aminotransferase)

 

 

Ref: Vasudevan 9/e p:117.

questions.text: Can the acetyl CoA, derived from fatty acid oxidation, be converted back into glucose to maintain blood glucose levels? What is the correct response based on human metabolic pathways?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) False

 

Option B:

 

Explanation:

 

Acetyl CoA cannot be converted into glucose in humans because the reactions of the citric acid cycle are not reversible, and there is no pathway that can convert acetyl CoA back to pyruvate or any other gluconeogenic precursors. This underscores the importance of the concept that while glucose can be converted into acetyl CoA, the reverse is not true, marking a one-way route towards energy production.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fate of Acetyl CoA

 

  • Fatty Acid Synthesis
  • Ketone Body Synthesis
  • Cholesterol Synthesis
  • TCA Cycle

 

Acetyl CoA cannot be converted to glucose as the link reaction is irreversible.

 

Ref: Vasudevan 9/e p: 141.

questions.text: A 42-year-old biochemist working on a project related to metabolic diseases encounters a patient’s chart with a rare metabolic disorder affecting the metabolism of certain fatty acids. The patient has an abnormal accumulation of fatty acids with an odd number of carbon atoms. Intrigued, the biochemist considers the metabolic fate of such fatty acids, specifically the conversion of propionyl-CoA, a product of their β-oxidation. He reflects on the pathway this metabolite takes in the process leading towards the citric acid cycle:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) D-Methylmalonyl CoA

 

Option C:

 

  • Propionyl CoA is first carboxylated to D-methyl malonyl CoA by a biotin dependent carboxylase.
  • One molecule of ATP is utilized to supply energy.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Acetyl-CoA: Acetyl-CoA is a product of even-numbered fatty acid oxidation, not directly from propionyl-CoA derived from odd-numbered fatty acids.

 

Option B: Acetoacetyl-CoA: Acetoacetyl-CoA is an intermediate in ketone body synthesis and is not directly related to the metabolism of propionyl-CoA.

 

Option D: Butyryl CoA: Butyryl CoA is a four-carbon acyl-CoA molecule that is not a direct product of propionyl-CoA metabolism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Propionyl-CoA, which is derived from the oxidation of fatty acids with an odd number of carbon atoms, is converted into D-Methylmalonyl CoA. This conversion involves a carboxylation reaction, which is catalyzed by the enzyme propionyl-CoA carboxylase, with biotin as a cofactor. D-Methylmalonyl CoA is then converted into succinyl-CoA, which can enter the citric acid cycle.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 205
